places_to_visit.name: Shurijo Castle
places_to_visit.description: Shurijo Castle is a UNESCO World Heritage site and the former palace of the Ryukyu Kingdom. The castle, originally built in the 14th century, showcases a unique blend of Chinese, Japanese, and Okinawan architectural styles. Though it suffered extensive damage during World War II and a recent fire, restoration efforts continue to bring back its historical glory. The castle grounds offer panoramic views of Naha and provide insight into the rich cultural history of Okinawa.

places_to_visit.name: Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium
places_to_visit.description: Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium is one of the largest and most impressive aquariums in the world. Located in the Ocean Expo Park, it features a massive tank known as the Kuroshio Sea, which houses whale sharks, manta rays, and a variety of other marine life. The aquarium also has exhibits on coral reefs, deep-sea creatures, and the diverse marine ecosystems surrounding Okinawa.

places_to_visit.name: Kokusai Street (Kokusai Dori)
places_to_visit.description: Kokusai Street, also known as Kokusai Dori, is the main shopping and entertainment district in Naha, Okinawa. The street is lined with shops, restaurants, cafes, and markets offering local crafts, souvenirs, and Okinawan delicacies. The vibrant atmosphere, especially in the evenings, makes it a must-visit for those looking to experience local culture and cuisine.

places_to_visit.name: Hiji Waterfall
places_to_visit.description: Hiji Waterfall is a stunning natural attraction located in the northern part of Okinawa Island. The hike to the waterfall takes you through lush forests, across suspension bridges, and along a tranquil river. The 26-meter-high waterfall is a serene spot for relaxation and enjoying the beauty of Okinawa's natural landscapes.

places_to_visit.name: Okinawa Peace Memorial Park
places_to_visit.description: The Okinawa Peace Memorial Park is dedicated to the memory of those who lost their lives during the Battle of Okinawa in World War II. The park includes the Peace Memorial Museum, which offers a poignant look at the war's impact on Okinawa and its people. The Cornerstone of Peace, inscribed with the names of all who perished, serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of peace.

places_to_visit.name: Cape Manzamo
places_to_visit.description: Cape Manzamo is a scenic coastal area famous for its dramatic cliffs and breathtaking views of the East China Sea. The name 'Manzamo' means 'a field for 10,000 to sit,' referring to the large grassy area atop the cliffs. The site is particularly popular at sunset, when the sky and sea are painted in vibrant colors.

places_to_visit.name: Zamami Island
places_to_visit.description: Zamami Island is part of the Kerama Islands and is known for its crystal-clear waters and vibrant coral reefs. It’s a popular destination for snorkeling, diving, and whale watching (seasonal). The island’s beaches, such as Furuzamami Beach, are pristine and less crowded, offering a perfect escape for relaxation and water activities.

places_to_visit.name: Gyokusendo Cave
places_to_visit.description: Gyokusendo Cave is a vast limestone cave located in Okinawa World, a theme park dedicated to showcasing Okinawan culture and natural wonders. The cave stretches for over 5 kilometers, with a 850-meter section open to the public. Visitors can walk through the cave’s impressive stalactites, stalagmites, and underground rivers, and then explore the cultural exhibits and traditional performances in Okinawa World.

places_to_visit.name: Nakagusuku Castle Ruins
places_to_visit.description: Nakagusuku Castle Ruins are the remains of a 15th-century fortress that was part of the Ryukyu Kingdom's defense system. Perched on a hill overlooking the East China Sea, the ruins offer spectacular views and a glimpse into Okinawa’s feudal past. The castle’s massive stone walls and strategically located gates reflect the architectural and military ingenuity of the time.

places_to_visit.name: Sesoko Island
places_to_visit.description: Sesoko Island is a small island connected to Okinawa's main island by a bridge. It’s known for its white sandy beaches, clear blue waters, and excellent snorkeling spots. Sesoko Beach and Anchor Bay are popular among visitors for their tranquil atmosphere and stunning natural beauty.

Respect local customs, especially at historical and sacred sites.
